Award.AwardTitle: Integrated Field Research and Spatial Analysis of Multiple Modalities of Political Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Lene Pedersen, Central Washington University, will undertake a three-year research program to investigate the intersecting structures and meanings of changing ties between rulers and ruled. The research will contribute to better understanding of the significant emerging phenomenon of hybrid systems of governance, as newly decentralized political systems are brought into relation with older, multi-level traditional systems, in many parts of the world today.

The research will be carried out in a polity in Bali, Indonesia. Taking a multi-sited and multi-method approach within a spatially explicit analytical framework, the study has three components. First, the researcher, working with a geographer and a Balinese research team, will map and analyze land-based, ritual, and kinship ties and obligations between princes and subjects. Second, she will examine the direct involvement of princes in multiple aspects of community life, such as ritual, irrigation, and political decision making Third, she will investigate how individuals perceive the princedom and the nation-state, and whether and to what degree these ideas are shaped by traditional political forms. From considering the present context of decentralization in Indonesia and the rise of Bali-Hindu ethno-nationalism, both of which have given new impetus to traditional institutions, Pedersen will also be able to examine the consequences of post-colonial land reforms and local political restructuring. Mapping and analysis utilizing a geographical information system database will allow her to determine the inter-scalar and multi-faceted web of ties to the palace and their relationships over time, while interviews and surveys will contribute ethnographic and generalizable data on associated behaviors and attitudes.

Dr. Pedersen's research is important because it takes a new approach to addressing long-standing questions, in Bali and elsewhere, about political change as inter-scalar political relations shift over time. Findings from this research will inform social science theory of political transformation in shifting contexts of institutional complexity. The project will also make important methodological contributions through its integration of ethnographic and survey approaches within a spatial framework. In addition, the research fosters international research collaboration and supports student education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project takes a multi-method and integrated approach to investigating material and symbolic aspects of relationships between traditional elites and local subjects in the context of post-colonial political change. It draws on in-depth fieldwork in a formerly semi-autonomous polity in Bali, Indonesia, which continues to exhibit classic characteristics of Southeast Asian kingdoms, referred to by scholars as mandala or negara, while Balinese generally use the term kerajaan, the realm of a raja. What was the basis of the indigenous, essentially feudal relationships, and how have they adapted to Indonesian nationalism, globalization and the massive expansion of tourism?   

 

The P.I. worked with a geographer and a Balinese research team to map non-private categories of land-ownership throughout the district, nestled in a fertile valley of irrigated rice agriculture contained by the topography of rivers and mountains. Combined with interviews of a surviving representative for each parcel of land, the analysis reveals a story in the landscape of the historical and contemporary role of land, ritual, kinship and patronage in establishing and maintaining (or "forgetting") reciprocal ties between traditional elites and subjects. Analysis utilizing a geographical information system database helps visualize our data and bring a new perspective to the discussion of the decentered yet integrated structure and organization of the Southeast Asian polity. The research further identifies the mechanisms for incorporating and maintaining peaceful relations with a minority Muslim community, and provides insight into critical junctures in the history of the polity, specifically periods of land reform, the political conflict and mass killings of 1965, and the present context of decentralization in Indonesia. The research yields an unusually frank picture from multiple perspectives, of the local rulers recent weakening in relation to their subjects and the democratic grassroots institutions of the polity. It tracks a rebellion in the village council in 2009, essentially a "traditional" grassroots democratic revolution to assert claims of villagers against caste hierarchical privilege. This is analyzed in comparison with the P.I.'s research in 1998, when the status of the local ruler and noble house, through a series of successful strategies, rose to a-long-time high in the context of Indonesia's national "revolution." 

 

This research is important because it takes a new approach to addressing long-standing questions about the complex nature of power and the role of land-based ties and patronage in the Southeast Asian polity, as inter-scalar political relations shift over time. Because the institutions are well articulated in Bali, and can be traced through eras of centralization and decentralization, we can study their expression and dynamics in ways that may have broader implications for understanding the phenomenon of hybrid systems of governance in other parts of the world, as newly decentralized political systems are brought into relation with older indigenous systems. The project also makes methodological contributions through its integration of ethnographic and survey approaches within a spatial and visual framework. Finally, the research has fostered international research collaboration, has supported student education in both Indonesia and the U.S, and, in addition to the P.I., has supported the careers of two young female faculty, in the US and Indonesia respectively.
